result.execSummary:
The defendant Joshua G. Bridgman was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Resisting or Obstructing an Officer, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 946.41(1).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes:
Defendant shall pay supervision fees as ordered by the Department of Corrections. 
If probation is ordered and ultimately revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due. 
All available enforcement actions will be used.
Towing charges of $784.00 shall be reimbursed to the victim's insurance company.
Obtain high school diploma or GED.

Write a letter of apology to the victim due within 30 days and approved by the agent.
Undergo counseling as deemed appropriate by the agent.

Cost Summary - Towing Charges
from S.A.S.
Restitution Summary

Defendant Joshua G. Bridgman in court with attorney Justin D. Wolff.  Kristi S. Tlusty appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Agreement on record by Ms. Tlusty.  State moved to amend Count 1 to a misdemeanor Obstructing an officer, under 946.41 - granted.  DE entered a plea of no contest to the amended charge.  Plea colloquy.  Court found plea given freely, voluntarily, and intelligently; accepted plea; found DE guilty and ordered entry of JOC.  Brief comments by counsel.  Court withheld sentence and placed DE on probtion for one year;  Pay court costs; restitution; towing costs; and DNA surcharge; letter of apology to the victim due within 30 days and approved by agent; attend counseling as recommended by agent; obtain high school diploma or GED.  34 days sentence credit.
